subject: Creativity
title: Satire: Comedy That Bites Back
description: A micro-lesson that makes Satire: Comedy That Bites Back usable.

hook.text: Jonathan Swift proposed eating Irish babies to solve famine.

buildup.text: Satire uses humor, irony, and exaggeration to criticize society, politics, or human nature.

discovery.text: The best satire is indistinguishable from reality â€” which is why The Onion's headlines are sometimes reported as real.

twist.text: Dictators fear satire more than journalism. Charlie Hebdo, South Park, and political cartoonists face real threats.

climax.text: Studies show satirical news (Daily Show, Last Week Tonight) produces better-informed viewers than traditional news.

punchline.text: Satire is the sharpest criticism wrapped in the softest packaging.

quiz.question: Why do dictators fear satire more than journalism?
options: Comedy makes criticism more memorable and harder to suppress
